Dear Mrs. Valdes:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on April 24,
2020. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Implementation Sustainability, and Exit Plan (ISEP) requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the ISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from
the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved; this includes identifying
behaviorally specific action steps.
o Repeat violations must include an explanation of why the previous
corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
 Individuals directly responsible for implementing the corrective action step for
each licensing statute and rule, Contract item, DHHS policy or ISEP section
citation, e.g. workers, supervisors, program managers, director, etc.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
implemented and completed.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved; this
includes identifying specific action steps for continuous monitoring.
o MiSACWIS users with access to the Book of Business, InfoView Reports
and the Monthly Child Welfare Management Report should incorporate the
use of these tools as well as other data management reports released by
the Department for continuous monitoring.
 Signature of the responsible party and date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Claudia Triestram, the area manager at (616) 552-3662.
Sincerely,
Paul Fatato, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12310 Initial evaluation
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written
initial foster home evaluation before certifying the home for
licensure.
One of two safety alerts reviewed uncovered a 3130A with significant missing
information. A description of this missing information is listed below in the safety
alert section of this report.
R 400.12325 License recommendation.
3) Except for an original license, an agency shall recommend to
the department the issuance of a regular license or the
continuation of an active license only when all rules are in
compliance or both of the following conditions exist:
(b) A written corrective action plan has been developed. The
plan shall be in compliance with all of the following
requirements:
(i) Specify the methods, the persons responsible, the time
frames for correction; methods for ensuring the safety of any
children placed in the home; how continuing compliance will be
maintained once compliance is achieved; consequences if the
corrective action plan is not completed; and what documentation
will be required to demonstrate compliance or completion.
One of eight open foster home case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the corrective action plan required for rule violations was completed in a timely
manner. The corrective action plan was scheduled to be completed on 9/30/19 but
not signed by the foster parents until 12/20/19.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(h) Recommendations regarding licensing action and any
required corrective action.
4

One of three special investigations reviewed did not have an appropriate corrective
action plan developed for the violations identified. This involved an adult family
member who was engaged in the behavior but not listed on the corrective action
plan.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter
One of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have each Updated
Service Plan completed within the required time frame. This involved one of twenty-
three Updated Service Plans reviewed. The report was completed 1 day late.
R 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(b),
shall include all of the following information:
(c) A summary of information pertinent to the updated services
plan received since the last service plan from the child, the
child’s parents or legal guardian, foster parents, referring
agency, and others, unless the agency documents why any of
these entities cannot be involved.
Two of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have each of the required
sections within the report completed. This involved two Updated Service Plans of
twenty-three USPs reviewed and both did not have the required information in the
placement details section.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
DHHS Policy Placement exception request (PER)
FOM 722.03
page 14-16
Was a PER completed when required and completed quarterly.
A placement must not be made if it will result in one of the
following:
• More than three foster children in that foster home.
5

• More than 75 miles from the home from which the child
entered custody; see Proximity to the Child’s Family in this item.
Two of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the required placement exception request was completed. In both case files, the
PER was still marked as “in progress” for a placement that had occurred on 9/15/19
and 6/14/19.
THIS IS A REPEAT VIOLATION FROM THE 2019 RENEWAL INSPECTION WITH
AN APPROVED CAP ON 4/15/2019 AND THE 2018 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH
AN APPROVED CAP ON 6/20/2018.
FOM 722-09C FOSTER CARE ACTION SUMMARY REQUIREMENTS
Page 1-2
The Foster Care/Juvenile Justice (FC/JJ) Action Summary,
DHHS-69 (RFF 69), is used whenever there is “action” on a
case.
Which Cases/When:
All foster care cases where there is:
1. A replacement.
2. Termination from foster care placement.
Three of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the DHHS-69 for a placement change was completed in a timely manner. This
involved four placement changes requiring the DHHS-69 that were completed 314,
181 and 62 days respectively after the effective date of the action.
Two of eight closed foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the closing DHHS-69 was completed in a timely manner. This involved two closing
DHHS-69s that were completed 213 and 97 days respectively after the effective date
of the action.
THIS IS A REPEAT VIOLATION FROM THE 2019 RENEWAL INSPECTION WITH
AN APPROVED CAP ON 4/15/2019 AND THE 2018 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH
AN APPROVED CAP ON 6/20/2018.
DHHS Policy Medical Passports
FOM 801 Page
11-13
Updated Medical Passport
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
6

One of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have all of the
requirements of the Medical Passport documented in the case file. This involved one
case file missing two Medical Passports. For this file there was a Medical Passport
present for 2/20/19 and then not again until 12/17/19.
THIS IS A REPEAT VIOLATION FROM THE 2019 RENEWAL INSPECTION WITH
AN APPROVED CAP ON 4/15/2019 AND THE 2018 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH
AN APPROVED CAP ON 6/20/2018.
DHHS Policy - Supervisory Approval USP
FOM 722-09 -
Page 27 -
Prior to finalizing, the USP along with the required assessments
(FANS, CANS, etc.) must be reviewed and approved by the
foster care supervisor only after a face-to-face meeting with the
foster care worker.
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
• Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
report date.
Two of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have the supervisors’
approval within the required fourteen-day time frame. This involved two of twenty-
three Updated Service Plans reviewed. These reports were approved by the
supervisor 21 and 2 days respectively after the 14-day time frame expired.
One of one open Independent Living case files reviewed did not have the Supervisor
approval within the fourteen-day time limit on each Service plan in the case file. This
involved one Updated Service Plan being approved seventeen-days outside of the
fourteen-day time limit.
THIS IS A REPEAT VIOLATION FROM THE 2019 RENEWAL INSPECTION WITH
AN APPROVED CAP ON 4/15/2019, THE 2018 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 6/20/2018, THE 2017 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 4/12/2017 AND FROM THE 2016 RENEWAL INSPECTION
WITH AN APPROVED CAP ON 5/18/2016.
DHHS Policy Required Participation in Development - Parents and Youth
FOM 722-08C over 14-Years Old & Foster Parent / Caregiver
Page 2
Upon completion of the parent-agency treatment plan and
service agreement, the parent is given a copy for review. Foster
care workers need to ensure the parent understands all areas
within the agreement. Parents and youths age 14 and older
must sign the PATP. If a parent or youth is unavailable or
refuses to sign the PATP, foster care workers must identify, and
document additional action needed to secure the parent’s
and/or youth’s participation in service planning and compliance
with the PATP. As the goals are achieved, modified or
expanded, the updated PATP will reflect this process. Parents
7

and youths age 14 and older must participate in the
development of each updated treatment plan, allowing for
opportunity to evaluate their progress towards completing goals.
The individual activities required by the foster parent/caregiver
to meet the specific individual needs of the child placed in their
home are included in the PATP. The foster parent/caregiver
must be included in the PATP process. The foster
parent/caregiver signature is required and indicates that the
foster parent/caregiver acknowledges and agrees to the
activities required to meet the needs of the child in their care.
Additionally, the PATP details the services and activities
provided by the foster care worker to assist the foster
parent/caregiver in caring for the child.
CI 17-096 Treatment Plan Signature Timeframes and
Documentation Requirements
When the treatment plan is completed, signatures for all
appropriate case members must be obtained. Signatures from
all appropriate case members, including youth ages 14 and
older for foster care and youth ages 11 and older for juvenile
justice, should be obtained before the corresponding court
hearing. All treatment plans with a report date of August 1,
2017, or later must have signatures from all appropriate case
members within 30 days of the report date.
Four of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have all of the required
signatures on the Parent Agency Treatment Plans. This involved one late caregiver
signature, one parent signature missing and three late parental signatures. The late
signatures occurred, 234, 34, 34 and 34 days respectively, after the report was
approved.
REPEAT VIOLATION FROM THE 2019 RENEWAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 4/15/2019, THE 2018 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 6/20/2018 AND THE 2017 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 4/12/2017.
DHHS Policy QUALITY VISITS
FOM 722-06H
Page 3
Quality visits between the caseworker and child have been
found to produce positive outcomes for children in foster care. A
quality visit is defined as one in which the caseworker:
- Meets with each child individually without the presence of
other individuals to give the child an opportunity to ask
questions.
- Assesses each child’s needs and takes appropriate action or
offers services in response to the identified need of each child.
8

- Shows interest in the individual child to build trust and
establish rapport.
- Shares and explains the case plan in a developmentally
appropriate way while allowing the child to ask questions and
express viewpoints.
Two of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation of a
quality home visit by the case worker for each home visit documented. This involved
three social work contacts.
One of one open Independent Living case file reviewed did not have documentation
of a quality home visit by the case worker for each home visit documented. This
involved two social work contacts.
REPEAT VIOLATION FROM THE 2019 RENEWAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 4/15/2019, THE 2018 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 6/20/2018, THE 2017 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 4/12/2017 AND FROM THE 2016 RENEWAL INSPECTION
WITH AN APPROVED CAP ON 5/18/2016.
DHHS Policy TIMELY ENTRY OF CASEWORKER CONTACTS
FOM 722-06H
page 15-16
All face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS, within
five business days of the contact. This includes the following:
Any face-to-face contacts with children, parents, or caregivers.
Seven of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation of
each social work contact being entered into the MiSACWIS system as required. This
involved fifty-one of one hundred and thirty-one (40%) home visit contacts entered
into MiSACWIS being entered timely.
REPEAT VIOLATION FROM THE 2019 RENEWAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 4/15/2019, THE 2018 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 6/20/2018 AND THE 2017 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 4/12/2017.
DHHS Policy Family Team Meeting
722-06B page 1-
7
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case Plan (ISP)
- within 14 calendar days before the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Permanency Goal Review at Six Months in Care Within 30
calendar days from the date the child has been in care for six
months.
9

Permanency Goal Change Within 30 calendar days before the
date of the goal change.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three business days
prior to a planned change of placement or no later than three
business days after an unplanned placement change.
Four of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the Family Team Meeting took place as required. This involves six Family Team
Meetings taking place outside of the prior thirty-day requirement.
One of one open Independent Living case files reviewed did not have the required
Family Team Meeting documented. This involved one FTM taking place prior to the
reporting period of the report by fourteen days.
REPEAT VIOLATION FROM THE 2019 RENEWAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 4/15/2019, THE 2018 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 6/20/2018 AND THE 2017 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 4/12/2017.
DHHS Policy CASEWORKER CONTACT WITH CHILD IN OUT-OF-HOME
FOM 722-06H PLACEMENT
page 5
At least one contact each month must take place at the child’s
placement location. Each contact must include a private
meeting between the child and the caseworker
One of one open Independent Living case file reviewed did not have a social work
contact documented for each month. There was not a home visit completed for the
month of April 2019.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Throughout this inspection is was noted that the agency is not consistently
coding uploaded information for each file. Several times, the same document
was coding differently. The agency indicated that there are several different
individuals who are conducting the uploading of documents and it was
suggested that they develop a system that will ensure each document has a
specific code when uploaded.
 At least seven times, required signatures were documented on upload forms
but the signature was present without the date that it was signed. A
discussion with the agency took place and it was suggested that they
increase their level of over-site to ensure that workers are obtaining the date
along with the signature.
 Throughout this inspection is was noted that several times documents were
not being loaded in the same location for each file reviewed. We discussed
the importance of consistent uploading and placing documents in the same
10

location for each file. They indicated that they would work on developing a
more consistent over-site system.
 There were several social work contacts that were not being identified as
home visit, thus causing difficulty in locating the home visits that were being
conducted as required. Again, this was discussed with the agency to ensure
that workers entering information in the MiSACWIS system are consistent and
uniform.
 Several DHHS-69 forms for various changes in the case file did have the
completed date but were missing the effective date. We processed the
importance of making sure the form is completed and the agency will identify
methods of over-site to ensure that this is being completed.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency did not request consultation at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period. However, there was one special evaluation that involved the foster
parents being cited for the use of corporal punishment with a foster child in the
home. The agency followed all requirements for an in-depth special evaluation and
completed all documentation within the case file. The agency found the family to be
in violation of Rule 400.9404. (3). The agency developed a corrective action plan
that was completed by the foster parents. However, the agency was cited for this
corrective action plan because an adult son in the home also engaged in the
“swatting” of the foster child and was not included in the corrective action plan. This
citation took place under Rule 400.12327 (5) (h) Special Evaluations.
Phone interviews were conducted with various staff, ranging from case managers to
administration. Each staff interviewed reported that they are adjusting well to the
current situation and have been able to maintain contact with their youth and/or
homes. They were able to share the procedures that the agency has taken to ensure
that the homes are safe. All staff report believing that administration is very
supportive of their efforts to provide appropriate services to the youth and/or homes.
VII. ANALYST REPORT DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The analyst interviewed four licensed homes and three unlicensed relative homes.
Safety identified with seven families. The concerns are as follows:
Safety Alert #1:
There are electrical outlets without covers in the room where the two youngest
children sleep. There is peeling paint in the two bedrooms that the children reside in,
11

and it is an older home. There is an unfinished wall in the hallway leading to the
youngest children's room with no plan of completion. The basement area of the
home, and the back hallway of the home, smells like animal urine.
Resolution: Documentation provided by the agency and documented in the
MiSACWIS system indicated the following resolution of this concern. On 1/16/20, a
home visit was completed by the foster care worker and this safety alert was
addressed with the relatives. The relatives purchased outlet covers and the worker
documented this with a picture. The worker documented through pictures and a
narrative that on 1/24/20, the family purchased paint and painted the area which had
chipped paint. The family also painted the unfinished wall and a narrative and picture
was provided. The worker documented the following when addressing the smell of
urine in the basement:
Due to the two oldest children being harmful to the animals in the
home the animals must be locked up, especially when the oldest child
is in the home. Until the children’s behaviors stabilize the animals will
continue to be in the basement while the children are awake and in
the home. During the time of the visit, it was Christmas break. As a
result, the pets spent more time in the basement as usual.
It was documented that the plan to eliminate the smell is to have the parents clean at
a minimum three times a week. This compliance will be monitored through monthly
visits by the foster care worker who will check on this specific issue.
Safety Alert #2:
The relative indicated that there had never been a worker that looked in her
bedroom at the residence as she would not allow anyone in there. The relative had
medications sitting all over the living room. She indicated that she had a lock box,
but refused to use it, as the foster child knows not to get into the medications. There
was quite a bit of clutter in the residence and there are at least two broken windows,
one in the front of the trailer, and one in the living room. The relative indicated that
they had just had a guardianship completed a couple of days before the worker
came out; it is unknown if the case is closed in the system. There is an approved
3130 in the system however the 3130 has many blank areas including the
assessment of the home, discipline plan, etc.
Resolution: Documentation provided by the agency indicates that phone contact
was made with the relative caregiver on 1/28/20 in which the issue of the storage of
medication was discussed. The relative caregiver placed all of the medication in the
lock box and provided a picture to the foster care worker to demonstrate compliance.
The reported clutter was discussed, and the relative caregiver indicated that this
clutter consisted of “craft supplies and papers”. The agency does not consider this to
pose a safety concern. In regards to the youth’s (17-year-old) room, this was
addressed, and it was not considered a safety concern. The clutter consisted of dirty
clothes on the floor. A case worker went to the home on April 20, 2020 to inspect the
home for compliance and was told by the relative caregiver that she has yet to follow
12

through with a repair to the windows. Documentation also indicates that because of
COVID-19 repairs have been placed on hold. This worker also asked to view the
caregiver’s room and it is documented that she replied, “It is none of your business
because the DHHS case is closed”. The worker also documented that the caregiver
is using the locked medication box and the “clutter” is not a safety concern. A review
of the case file in MiSACWIS confirms this information. A review of the 3130A
provided the following documentation: the report is very limited on the description of
the different aspects, however, each section of the report is addressed. Some of the
deficiencies of the report include a description where the smoke and carbon
monoxide detectors are located, very limited description of the caregivers attitudes
towards the child’s parents, very limited narrative of her willingness to participate in
the child’s services, poor narrative to the caregivers support of the child returning to
their parents, no description of the family vehicle, no license for the family dog,
limited information about the family being current on bills when the family identified
the primary stressor is financial, and almost no description of the impact of fostering.
There is no reference to the worker viewing the caregiver’s room nor any reference
to any broken windows. Therefore because of the limited information provided and
the lack of refence to specific issues a violation was established. This is noted in the
above findings.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
